title: 105_s314
content: The text chunk is a section title. The "Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998" requires executive agencies to submit annual lists of non-inherently governmental activities performed by Federal Government sources. The list must include the fiscal year, number of employees needed, and the responsible Federal Government employee. The "Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998" mandates executive agencies to submit annual lists of non-inherently governmental activities performed by Federal Government sources. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget reviews and consults with agency heads on the final list for each fiscal year. Once the list is reviewed, the agency head transmits it to Congress and makes it public, while the Director publishes a notice in the Federal Register. The list of non-inherently governmental activities is made public. Changes to the list must be promptly shared with the public and Congress. Executive agencies must competitively select private sector sources for activities on the list. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall use a competitive process to select private sector sources for executive agency activities. The head of the executive agency must ensure fair cost comparisons when deciding to contract with a private source. When contracting with private sector sources for executive agency activities, fair cost comparisons must be ensured, taking into account all relevant costs such as liability insurance, employee benefits, and overhead costs. SEC. 3. CHALLENGES TO THE LIST. An interested party can challenge the omission or inclusion of an activity on a published list. An interested party is defined as a private sector source with a direct economic interest in the activity or a representative of a business association. An interested party, defined as a private sector source with a direct economic interest or a business association representative, can challenge the inclusion of an activity on a published list. The challenge must be submitted to the executive agency within 30 days of the list's public availability. Within 28 days of receiving a challenge, the executive agency must make a decision and notify the party submitting the challenge. The process for appealing a decision involves submitting a written notification with rationale and explanation of the right to appeal. An interested party can appeal within 10 days to the head of the executive agency, who must decide within 10 days and provide a written notification with rationale. SEC. 4. APPLICABILITY. This Act applies to executive agencies including executive departments, military departments, and independent establishments, but does not apply to the General Accounting Office, Government corporations, or nonappropriated funds instrumentalities. The Act applies to executive agencies, including departments and establishments, but excludes the General Accounting Office, Government corporations, and nonappropriated funds. Certain depot-level maintenance and repair for the Department of Defense is defined in section 2460 of title 10, United States Code. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Federal Government source" refers to any organization within an executive agency that uses Federal Government employees to perform an activity. The term "inherently governmental function" means a function that is intimately related to the public interest and requires performance by Federal Government employees, including activities that involve discretion in applying Federal Government authority or making value judgments for the Federal Government. The term "inherently governmental function" involves interpreting and executing US laws to bind the government, protect national interests, affect private individuals, control government officers, and have ultimate acquisition control. The term "inherently governmental function" involves ultimate control over the acquisition, use, or disposition of US property, excluding functions like gathering information or providing advice to government officials, and ministerial tasks like building security or housekeeping. The Act will be effective on October 1, 1998.
